column1: Before 14 August 2021, will an executive order be signed or federal legislation become law that would forgive $10,000 or more in principal on federal student loan debts for at least five million student loan borrowers?
column6: ['Finance', 'US Politics', 'US Policy']

5 Key Takeaways From Biden’s Extension Of Student Loan Relief - Forbes https://www.forbes.com/sites/adamminsky/2021/08/07/5-key-takeaways-from-bidens-extension-of-student-loan-relief/ Sat, 07 Aug 2021 13:43:11 GMT
Moratorium extended to January, no chance of loan forgiveness this week.
It was a Democratic campaign promise.. so it will never happen.

This is more likely closer to the midterms. Voters have short memories.

+3 "The Department of Education has canceled a total of $1.5 billion in student loan debt for nearly 92,000 students, who were victims of for-profit college fraud, since President Joe Biden took office." It's a start.
updating
-1 passage of time

Times running out on this one. Not going to happen, because people that understand the issue realize that this disproportionally benefits upper income households (i.e. doctors and attorneys). Not a very progressive policy at the end of the day.

Not enough to affect question resolution: https://greekreporter.com/2021/06/18/joe-biden-cancels-3-billion-worth-of-student-debt/
Updating
staying at 5% for a while longer

Biden offering debt forgiveness on $10,000 for 5,000,000 followers defrauded by for profit colleges shows political will to accomplish this, but likely pushes it back in the agenda before August 14th.
Pressure seems low given the freeze through September plus other more pressing legislative items.
I wasn't watching this one. With deadline extended until September. It doesn't seem this is going to happen in the timeframe.
No change
-5 on passage of time
No inclusion of student debt in latest budget, and seems unlikely he will sign executive order when he is getting a lot done through legislative process:

Reducing significantly because of doubts about whether the Education Department will finish their report, and frankly I just don't think student debt is a huge priority for Biden right now. Even if he does end up doing it, he may very well compromise and cancel less than 10,000.

Biden Drops Student Loan Forgiveness From Latest Budget - Forbes https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/05/21/biden-drops-student-loan-forgiveness-from-latest-budget/ Sat, 22 May 2021 03:04:31 GMT

Going to zero and throwing in the towel on my highly contrary view against the crowd that this would happen before August 2021. The WaPo reports that next week's budget leaves out any mention of student debt cancellation.[1] My mistaken view was so strong based on my belief that Biden and his senior advisors had learned from Obama's failures of incrementalism. I think that view holds but the politics are just not in their favor with the 50/50 Senate and the intransigence from Manchin and Synema to stop minority-rule in the Senate. I did not give enough weight to their clearly enunciated views. When I did consider them, I engaged in hand waving to believe those two could be persuaded "some how."
https://hillreporter.com/judge-orders-cruella-devos-to-testify-in-lawsuit-over-loan-forgiveness-101529
Dropping on time but less than straight line as the rhetoric is still continuing.
They will have to come back with a better plan , as it stands right now, it is no passing any vote.

Just not happening. What most people do not understand, despite the aggressive push from progressives, is that this proposal disproportionality benefits the upper class, to a lesser degree, but not insignificantly, the middle class and barley the lower class. There is really no incentive for the Biden Administration, based on their stated policy objectives, an EO would be inconsistent.

Democrats Propose To Forgive Student Loans With 4 Changes - Forbes https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/05/09/democrats-urge-immediate-student-loan-relief-and-propose-4-ways-to-fix-student-loan-forgiveness/ Sun, 09 May 2021 13:02:49 GMT

The Biden Administration doesn't want to rush into this. They have to make sure the DOE's legal memo on whether there is executive branch authority to cancel the loans is ironclad: https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/04/03/biden-student-loans-review-could-mean-this-for-student-loan-cancellation/?sh=6f1a36d08cbd Next, there's still lots of time. Student loans are all in deferment until October: https://www.nerdwallet.com/article/loans/student-loans/student-loan-covid-forbearance
Very much alive. https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/05/09/democrats-urge-immediate-student-loan-relief-and-propose-4-ways-to-fix-student-loan-forgiveness/
Updating upwards on account of discussion
-10% based on this https://time.com/nextadvisor/in-the-news/student-loan-forgiveness-predictions/
Going from 20 to 0.
Only way this is going to happen is by Executive Order and it is unclear if it can be done via an Executive Order.
This might be something to consider when midterms are getting close in order to spur student, young people, and recently educated, participation in the election, groups that are leaning democrat.

Biden has unveiled his next big round of proposals. Now is the time when we would hope to see it and it hasn't materialized. Particularly given the amount of money Biden is considering spending I don't think this policy proposal makes the cut. We will see which laws get passed. If enough of them get blocked, I suspect Biden might do something unilaterally.
Whoops, forgot to actually adjust the forecast.
-5 passage of time
student loan payments remain frozen
The Biden administration has asked DOE if they have authority to do this. So they are certainly thinking about it.

Raising on the news that Biden is considering cancelling up to 50,000 by executive order (https://www.forbes.com/sites/adamminsky/2021/04/01/biden-actively-considering-cancelling-student-loan-debt-of-up-to-50000/?sh=22044ae938e8).
Small bump in numbers dues to the confirmation that amendments to budget reconciliation measures are not party to the filibuster rule.
I am selfishly hoping this happens and based this number on a couple comments.

+6 on Klain’s comments today.[1]. My reading of Klain’s framing is that Biden will act when he has the views of Department of Education and Justice. This DOE is clearly disposed to cancel debt, having already cleared $1 billion for defrauded students at for-profit schools. The question is whether the DoJ’s Office of Legal Counsel is more likely than not to side with those who believe the executive branch has authority on its own to cancel student debt apart from the legislature. Executive branch lawyers tend to reflexively assert executive power. The acting head of OLC Christopher Schroeder was brought back in after serving in the OLC under Obama and Clinton. He was also a staffer for Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee. This suggests he can be relied upon to be friendly to the mainstream of respectable Democratic views on the law. I am guessing he will agree with all of those smart Harvard lawyers who say the president can cancel student debt on his own.
"1. Don’t expect student loan cancellation anytime soon" https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/03/29/heres-the-latest-on-student-loan-cancellation/
Change: -10
-10 on passage of time, the growing possibility it doesn't happen before August, and following the crowd a bit.
https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-3-trillion-infrastructure-fbf6fcb8ca51ab5b4b45b5318046e831
No change in forecast, but with immigration an increasingly pressing issue right now, I don't think Biden will try to use valuable political capital on student loan forgiveness this year.
Increasing divisiveness in Congress. This issue is unlikely to be the one that Democrats fall on their sword for

With the recent $1.9T congressional relief bill (a whopping 10% of GDP) signed into law, I cannot see how Congress could pass another large scale wealth transfer bill that would add to the federal debt. Dropping forecast from 10% to 5%
Exec order: will DOJ find it within the president's existing authority? will they rule early enough for Biden to act before 14 Aug? Will he do so if they rule affirmatively?
Change:+5

I am going to increase on the information that Congress did not include it in the COVID relief package, which may incentivize the Executive Branch to take it upon themselves. Timing and legality is still in question so this I think is reflected in my probability forecast for this update. Maybe student loan relief was not included so it would not be a topic of debate in a bill that was much desired among many Americans.
Recent press reports suggest upcoming stimulus bill sets path for student debt cancellation.
https://thehill.com/policy/finance/541886-senate-relief-bill-would-exempt-student-loan-forgiveness-from-taxes

I'm gonna reduce due to the delay in seeing if the executive order is lawful. I think if it is seen as a lawful option for Biden, it shouldn't take this long to approve. The fact that they even had to probe its lawfulness is doubt to him actually being able to sign an EO. If I were to give it a 100% chance of success in 4 years, passing it within this question window gives you an 11% hit probability. I am going to trust that not everything Biden aspires to do will be done within the first year.

New news, bad optics for me: "Another factor that may impact the timing and likelihood of student debt forgiveness being enacted is how smoothly new Department of Education officials are transitioned into power.
This is unlikely before August, I think the other side of the aisle only has the stomach for one major fiscal policy / handout in a year.
This tweet seems to indicate that it's highly unlikely to happen through executive action by the expiration date: https://twitter.com/PressSec/status/1357398773782237186

-2 from my previous forecast because the Senate Parliamentarian recently ruled that reconciliation could not be used for minimum wage increase and is likely to rule the same way on student loan debt relief.

-10. Still think this is more likely than not before the next Senate election, just not sure it can get done in the question timeframe. It's not attached to the new COVID relief currently so to me that lowers the likelihood of it happening in the timeframe.

Biden is unlikely to use EO for student loan relief. He has supported $10,000 in aid but he has too many other priorities (COVID, Foreign Affairs, etc.) to justify student loan relief. (https://www.nerdwallet.com/article/loans/student-loans/joe-biden-student-loans.)

Conversations around $15 federal minimum wage have evaporated. With stimulus talks already on the table for 2021 I do not see student loan forgiveness becoming a political topic for 2021 while schools are not in proper session, and the public is becoming worried about federal spending in the wake of COVID relief driving asset prices up.
Change: +22.
Yes, but not by 14 August.
+10% for DOJ review of executive action for Biden (https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/02/17/biden-will-ask-doj-to-review-student-loans/?sh=7e9805933605)

Crowd's too confident in a no on this one. There's going to be a stimulus bill and DoJ is reviewing his ability to do an executive order. He's signalled he's willing to do $10,000 when progressive ask is $50,000. I'm going to go contrarian and say more likely than not.
Agree with @Jibreel_PCV, Biden considered executive action but he would have done it by now if he will at all. -5%

Based on Biden's comments at the town hall on Tuesday and Jen Psaki's follow-up comments, I continue to believe $10,000 for at least five million borrowers is highly likely in some form before August 14. The second CARES Act is on track to pass via reconciliation in mid-March, according to news media, allowing a vehicle to attach this provision.[1] Reconciliation bills cannot be filibustered.

Change (-10): Biden last night signaled that the executive order is pretty much off the table. I think we'll see if this makes its way into the next reconciliation bill, but I'm becoming less and less hopeful.

Back up to 25% on Biden saying that is his limit. He could sign an EO that would do that. I think even that would be challenged in court ujt he seems comfortable doing it. Alternate is he goes with income repayment plans. It is my observation that he is a product of the legislative branch and truly belkeves it is Congress responsibility to budget and spend.
Biden says he's "prepared" to do it by executive order for $10k. This seems fairly likely to happen one way or another, the big question in my mind is whether it happens by August.
Schumer and Warren say it has to be 50k. Biden says no. Probably a compromise will be found that will include a sum higher than 10k.

Change (-5). Reasoning: I'm starting to wonder if Schumer is calling on Biden to do this because he knows Manchin is going to vote against it. That would lower the probability of doing it through another budget reconciliation bill.
After blocking impeachment the Democrats will go for an easy win. This will be a bipartisan bill so will be an uphill battle.

Lowering to 10. 1)path via legislation blocked by filibuster. 2) path via reconciliation is viable. 3) path be executive order to directly (in the order) state amount to forgive is very slim. To much responsibility for Prez to take directly for such a complicated topic and he has indicated an aversion to debt forgiveness directly. 4) path via EO directing Dept of Ed to start a rulemaking to determine the threshold income limits and debt forgiveness tiers and implement process is most likely but would take 6 months to wonk (yes, wonk) out. This resolution would miss the question timeline and if it did occur prior to aug 14 it would not explicitly satisfy the question because the actual EO would not have forgiven the debt nor the thresholds (only directing DOE to issue regulaions to forgive the debt).

Lowering confidence due to the reluctance to budge upward by very thoughtful people on here. There still seems to be uncertainty whether Biden would actually commit to EO and whether the numbers are enough to trigger a YES. Additionally, the outside view of bills passing in Congress in general is something like 4%.

The one part of the bill that has been publicly released so far does not have anything in it on this debt forgiveness: https://oversight.house.gov/sites/democrats.oversight.house.gov/files/Committee%20on%20Oversight%20and%20Reform%20Coronavirus%20Relief%20Measures%20Legislation.pdf This indicates it's a bit lower priority, at least for now. Therefore lowering my odds
M feeling is Joe would prefer to use Executive orders ONLY when necessary.
tucking in with the crowd for a bit...
Increasing by 5% due to Biden considering executive action

I am with @Francis_Urquhart's high-confidence update. In addition, I had read the question wrong all along. I gave low estimates because I thought only Executive Order would count as YES when, in fact, a federal legislation from Congress would suffice. With Biden's willingness to consider Executive Order, my confidence rebounds upward. Now the question is whether Congress will propose a law; if yes, Biden still signs. The only way this goes NO is if both forget about this because of low priority. However, they have been talking about this for several months. Therefore, I do think they consider this high priority. And with the pandemic and looming fall semester around the question deadline, I see incentive for Congress to tackle this problem - there is already support from leadership in the majority.

Raising my estimate due to comments by White House spox Jen Psaki saying the President is considering executive action on up to $50,000 in debt cancellation.(1) Even compromising on $10,000 now fulfills Biden’s campaign promise and makes him appear to be governing for the middle.

Change (-4). Two bits of news: 1) Dems look likey to use Budget reconciliation for the covid stimulus bill. Reconciliation can only be used once per year so it seems less likely this will be done through legislative action. 2) Progressive senators and Chuck Schumer called on Biden again to cancel the debt with an executive order today. This suggests to me that they also don't think it will happen legislatively and that they are not letting the issue die.
Decreasing because negotiations on the second COVID stimulus bill will probably take some time

Moving to more or less in line with consensus. Can rationalise as not in this stimulus bill, potentially there is a 2/3rds or lower chance of another stimulus bill and perhaps a 1/3 chance it makes it into the new one if not in this one. That gets you to just over 20% as a cap, probably should be a bit lower, but then there is a residual chance it gets done through some other means.

Lowering based on historical NO (crowd and myself) and the conjunction fallacy. If Biden submits a budget to Congress, it could or could not include anything related to student loans. I think Biden is inclined to delegate this to Congress. If he does not submit anything pertaining to student loans, it may not be a priority (maybe they spend too much and are being conservative with funds) or he will indeed sign an EO on his own hands.
Going now way BELOW the crowd. 6.5 mos to the close.

Federal student loan payment are currently paused until September and President Biden has stated that he wants Congress to pass legislation on this topic. These two factors decrease the chance that an executive order will be signed to forgive federal student loan debts. Congress will likely pass legislation on this topic but I think it will happen after the 14 August deadline. If a bill is introduced in the House of Representatives or Senate I will adjust this forecast.

"Members of the subreddit are often young retail traders and investors who ignore fundamental investment practices and risk management techniques, so their activity is considered gambling. The growing popularity of no-commission brokers and mobile online trading has potentially contributed to the growth of such trading trends. Members of the communities often see high-risk day trading as an opportunity to quickly improve their financial conditions and obtain additional income. Some of the members tend to use borrowed capital, like student loans, to bet on certain "meme stocks" that show popularity within the community.[...]
+3% for the possibility of the Dems dismantling the filibuster (https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/25/politics/senate-republicans-power-sharing-deal/index.html).

"Higher education expert Mark Kantrowitz said Biden’s Covid relief plan focuses on the most pressing issues of the public health crisis, and that debt cancellation will likely come later. 'I think the odds of some student loan forgiveness being enacted is as good as it has ever been,' Kantrowitz said. 'But legislation probably won’t be proposed until late summer or early fall.' [...] Arguing that the legislative path is too time-consuming and risky, advocates and other Democrats are calling on Biden to cancel the debt sooner through executive action. The Senate’s top Democrat, Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., is pressing Biden to immediately forgive $50,000 per borrower. 'All you need is the flick of a pen,' Schumer said last month. 'You don’t need Congress.' " https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/23/why-bidens-student-loan-forgiveness-may-be-delayed.html

Odds have gone up. The request is expected to be made to Congress: https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/08/student-loan-forgiveness-could-be-more-likely-but-challenges-remain-.html It appears this can be passed through reconciliation.

This will be an unpopular move, seen as a bailout of irresponsible students. Biden will try to navigate forward in a way to help this constituency, but it won't be an immediate reduction of debt by a lot of students. Rather it will be some sort of path for the 'deserving' to get their student debts relieved, like doing public service for some period of time. This will be for the optics.

-20% due to Joe Biden extending the freeze on student debt until September(https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/01/20/biden-pauses-student-loans-for-8-months-what-it-means-for-student-loan-cancellation/?sh=54590b4454da). They won’t be a priority in the near future.

Forbes article suggests Biden is less likely to pursue this through executive order. Results of GA runoff improves his chances of pushing something through Congress. More analysis need to determine the two quantitative metrics: 1) $10,000 and 2) 5.0 million borrowers.
Whilst I think it would be easier to get this passed, I think the economy post-COVID (if we are post COVID) won't be in a position to allow such expenditure.
Need more discussion to allow this happens.
I think I was too high in my assessment of the Biden administration’s chance of doing this with senate control, which I set at 85% previously.

9. Before 14 August 2021, will an executive order be signed or federal legislation become law that would forgive $10,000 or more in principal on federal student loan debts for at least five million student loan borrowers? a. Initial Assessment: Ok, so there are a couple parts to this Q. First:

Change (-4). Reasoning: student loan forgiveness was not included in the initial 1.9 Billion plan proposed by Joe Biden. This means that it is likely to be included in the second round, which I would expect will be much more partisan and contentious. We sill see how hard the GOP fights to kill it there, but the fact that it won't be part of the first round of Corona re-organization is a small knock against its probability.

If it's truly a 40% chance, then I definitely wouldn't pay down any student loan principal right now. I think it's more like 20% at best. Biden now has all the power he wants to continue the pause on student loan repayments, which he announced this morning he plans to do: https://www.cbsnews.com/news/student-loan-payments-pause-biden-extend/

+20 on Democratic control. I could definitely see this happening as part of a future coronavirus relief package. But I'm not confident due to moderate Senators and I'm not sure what role the filibuster might play.

$-7% Now that the Dems control the Senate they can negotiate a favorable stimulus bill. However, the final version might not have the student loan payments as there will be a lot of horsetrading. Without the pressure of a do-nothing congress, I doubt Biden will use an executive order.
I am not changng my forecast but updating reasoning with Dems win of Senate.

Increasing to 75% because: Now that Dems hold both houses, it's more likely that student loans will be the focus of the Congressional agenda and get passed (https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackfriedman/2021/01/05/2000-stimulus-checks-bad-news-for-student-loan-forgiveness/?sh=6b8c6d834969).

Even with the recent announcement of the Georgia Senate race giving Democrats control of WH/HoR/Senate (at least before a recount), I do not see any student loan forgiveness being legislated before the fall of 2021
I am torn between Biden wanting to make this plan happen but Biden not wanting to overstep his already Blue/Democrat Congress, which can more easily relatively pass a law that he supports.
Slight increase on Democrats improved chances in GA runoff elections.
Up 10 on Democratic controlled Senate prospects looking slightly better.

As the gridlock frustrates Biden’s coalition, due to Mitch McConnell’s intransigence, he and his team will seek a quick win in the form of an EO, using their power to forego collecting debt for low income people as well as those in public service, teachers, civil servants, and military.

I still think Biden is going to be skeptical about using Executive power to sign such an order. However, I don't see that much strength to his reluctance. Therefore, I increase my confidence of a YES resolution to near but just under the crowd consensus. I also question the timeframe, the probability that he will be in office come January, and the probability he will remain in office.

This feels like a formula that is not based on economic theory, but rather politicians would consider "middle ground" and that they could explain to their constituents when they are running for re-election.
Biden needs to do an executive order to satisfy the most liberal branch of his party. $10K is a good hurdle.
Some debt forgiveness is possible but probably not so soon and probably will start small.

This article clarifies Biden's views on an "imperial presidency." I will start off low on probability. Even if Biden pressures Congress to do so, one half would have the fuel to push it forward but the other half may stop it. Passing laws in general let alone one specifically about student loans will be quite a stretch. https://www.complex.com/life/2020/12/joe-biden-unlikely-to-cancel-50000-student-loan-debt-executive-order

In a Forbes article today, President-elect Biden said that he would be inclined (and legally able) to cancel about $10,000 in student loan debt, but would be unwilling to do as much as $50,000 as some Democratic legislators have been pushing for. https://www.forbes.com/sites/adamminsky/2020/12/23/biden-says-he-is-unlikely-to-cancel-50000-in-student-loan-debt-by-executive-order/?sh=2e21d07c15b6
I note I'm below the crowd, but will stay put till after inauguration and THIS has finally occurred. VERY FUNNY TO WATCH!!!
This would be a method of providing CoVid-19 "stimulus" assistance to a substantial portion of the population.
will expect some foregiveness but not at the $10,000 level.
Postponement left out of stimulus bill, leading to an oncoming crisis that will need to be addressed quickly.

Will an EO be signed? Maybe. But I think the administration is going to have higher priorities out the gate, like combatting the pandemic and making a more equitable economic recovery. While student loan debt is part of that equation, I think Biden will avoid any unilateral actions at first.
Americans like free money.

Biden wants to do this and the main players of the Democratic Party (Clyburn, Schumer, Etc ) also want him to. I doubt he wants to do it through executive action but if stimulus negotiations once he's in the office go poorly, which there is a good chance of, they will. The only universe I see this not happening in is the universe where there is a stimulus bill that is close to Democratic expectations but this is not included in it. However, as with all proactive legislation I lean against it.

I have a 45% chance that Democrats control the senate. In that case, with Schumer’s support this feels like a good chance of happening - I think there are a lot of things Biden would trade it for though and a close senate is never easy so maybe 75% likelihood?
Perfect followup to post covid support.

So I think there is a decent chance that this will happen. However, I think part of that is that it may happen through legislation. The odds of this executive order occurring on the stated timeline depend heavily on how stimulus negotiations go once Biden comes into office. Precedent from 2008, when Obama came in, suggests that a measure like a stimulus bill which is both good for the economy and something that the GOP could blame the Dems for, will not face stiff congressional opposition and it would not surprise me if this measure makes its way into the stimulus bill. However that itself depends on who controls the Senate since there is a difference between McConnell not vigorously opposing something and actively working towards it. Even if it doesn't get done in the stimulus, if the stimulus meets enough democratic priorities I suspect Biden will not feel pressured to use unilateral executive action on a measure that most policy wonks consider to be a band-aid solution and bad for the institution of the presidency.
Dropping substantially. Biden has balancing act to prove he’s not a socialist (basically an expletive in USA but accepted on most of the planet ;) )
According to Forbes, Biden is less inclined to pursue executive order route. If the Democrats maintain control of the Senate, it seems more likely he will pursue this through Congress.

While the incoming Biden administration will say it supports student loan forgiveness, pushing through a plan in Congress will be a different story. Student loan forbearance with 0% interest was provided during COVID-19 pandemic, but the omnibus stimulus package did not include any further student loan relief. Most student debt is for middle-age adults in households that have higher earnings, not younger professionals, so the burden to repay loans will likely remain on them.
Biden will not fight the executive order battle with this issue, and little chance of passing this through Republican Senate.

Joe Biden has expressed a desire to work with both parties on advancing his policies. It would be tough to do this if he upset Republicans by signing an executive order to do that. As much as I'd love to see that happen, I don't think it will. And, banning a Democratic flip of the Senate after the runoff, I don't think anything's going to get done legislatively with a Rep-controlled Senate.

Jill Biden is a community college professor and its a corner stone of the progressives in the party that is one of the least controversial bills or EO that President Biden could get passed or sign into law.

Joe Biden has expressed a desire to limit his Executive Orders. The current plan as he has laid out utilizing executive orders is to limit them to reversing President Trump’s Executive Orders. Biden feels that the orders undercut the authority and responsibility of congress and would rather see legislation on divisive matters such as gun control and student loan forgiveness.

While I'm very strongly against forgiving Student Loans, I, unfortunately, believe that between the CoronaVirus devastation on the Economy, the massive deaths that Trump's failure to deal with the virus has wrought, the nation will need something like this to spark hope among the population. The Republicans will fight and claim Fiscal Responsibility, a platform they conveniently land on whenever they need to stand against something which actually helps people. The chance of it occurring is also predicated on the need for both Georgia Senate races landing in the hands of the Democrats. If the senate is 51/49 Republican, student loan relief stands little (near 0 chance)
This is well supported by citizens - and the progressive members of congress
It is needed and rational but the representatives and senators fight too much and are too slow.

Biden will be under pressure from progressives to take meaningful actions on their goals. I believe Biden will not shift much from his centrist orientation, but I also think he will take easy victories if he can. While many progressive priorities will require legislative change (with Ds controlling the Senate), this action is arguably-enough within the province of executive action. There's a fairly strong chance, then, that Biden will use this approach to ease, relatively easily, some of the progressive pressure on him.

There are 4 ways 10k can be forgiven: by law, by an executive order specifying the monetary amount, by the secretary of education on own initiative to compromise the debt, or by an executive order directing the sec of ed to make a rule to reduce the principle of debt without the order specifying the monetary amounts.

Not sure how much insight I have to add here as politics is not really my thing. Just an initial forecast from reading the articles linked in the questions and reading the rationales below. Look forward to forecasting this question. It'll definitely get me out of my comfort zone.
Two competing opinions about doing this by executive action

1) Biden can simply continue the pause on collecting the loans and get the same result, economically. 2) Even if Democrats win the 2 Georgia Senate seats, at 50-50 the Senate can be no more progressive than the most conservative Democrat: Joe Manchin. Manchin has been much more in favor of simplified and easier repayment options rather than outright forgiveness. See for example this bill that he cosponsored: https://www.manchin.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/manchin-reintroduces-legislation-to-simplify-student-loan-repayment-programs
Election payback will be made before August by executive order. Since there is no pain and only glory in doing this there will be no resistance from anyone who could prevent it.

They don't say this, but what a certain subset of my fellow Republicans fear most in the world is upward mobility. They view everything as a zero-sum activity, so if someone else does well, they suppose it must have come from their stash. Letting the unwashed masses exit college without crushing debt threatens to increase upward mobility; it has certainly worked that way for the Honourable Members. So the Senate Rs won't go for it.

He wants to do this and to do it as part of COVID relief, but I'm skeptical that he would try it via executive order when the legality of that is debated. And I don't see a bill including this going anywhere as long as Republicans control the Senate, so that drops the probability lower especially since Republicans look most likely to hold the Senate.
